Message.Title: Obama admin knew embasy attack probable but did not protect staff
Message.Msg: This explains why Obama is avoiding the press and major news outlets are trying to divert attention from Obama's failure by placing blame on a movie. Is this still America? The way we are being lied to is unblievable, we are now forced to rely on foriegn sources to get information. According to senior diplomatic sources, the US State Department had credible information 48 hours before mobs charged the consulate in Benghazi, and the embassy in Cairo, that American missions may be targeted, but no warnings were given for diplomats to go on high alert and "lockdown", under which movement is severely restricted. Senior officials are increasingly convinced, however, that the ferocious nature of the Benghazi attack, in which rocket-propelled grenades were used, indicated it was not the result of spontaneous anger due to the video, called Innocence of Muslims. Patrick Kennedy, Under-Secretary at the State Department, said he was convinced the assault was planned due to its extensive nature and the proliferation of weapons. There is growing belief that the attack was in revenge for the killing in a drone strike in Pakistan of Mohammed Hassan Qaed, an al-Qa'ida operative who wasfrom Libya, and timed for the anniversary of the 11 September attacks. Senator Bill Nelson, a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said: "I am asking my colleagues on the committee to immediately investigate what role al-Qa'ida or its affiliates may have played in the attack and to take appropriate action."

Topic.Title: Embassy attack - Romney does Obama's job

Message.Msg: you expanded my remarks If only I had to expand your remarks. On 9/11 you stated--quite plainly-- the President sympathizes with the terrorists who attacked us in 2001. In a thread requesting unity on the anniversary of those attacks no less. Yes, I am sensitive when my country is insulted. You do it consistently and often. Our diplomats do not and did not apologize for American values. They stood by them, in the field, and four gave their lives for them. For the likes of you and Romney to denigrate them from the homefront, during an ongoing crisis, is awful. You and your friends on this MB are hateful, divisive, fearful and gullible. These are not the American values our soldiers and FSOs die to defend. They die for tolerance, unity, courage and reason. These are American values.

Message.Title: This board just gets wackier and wackier...
Message.Msg: ”…the Border Patrol has pics of Arabs with rocket launchers, coming across our southern border.” - robthemanofcoloralbeitbeige Well, rob, that’s really big news. I can’t wait to see them. Unfortunately, all but the delusionally impaired are asking a legitimate question; If pictures of Arabs with rocket launchers coming across our southern border existed, wouldn’t Jan Brewer, Rick Perry or Sheriff Joe Arapio already have made sure they were in the hands of FOX News or any of the other Non-MSM arbiters of the truth from whom you get this type of information? But let’s examine the logic of this, another of your sage and well-documented allegations. By “coming across our southern border”, I assume you meant they were sneaking in – or was this guy just standing in line on the International Bridge Customs crossing from Ciudad Juarez to El Paso with the other migrant workers, except for the rocket launcher slung over his shoulder? Custom Agent: “What are you doing with that, sir? Answer in Arabic tinged, fake Spanish accent, English: “The-e-e-s, Senor? The-e-ess new speedy papaya picker, Senor.” Not likely, so let’s assume your pictures are of night crossings in a desolate area using night vision cameras. Let me ask you rob - If you had such a picture, how would we know they are Arabs? If you were an Arab trying to sneak through the border, would you be wearing your traditional keffiyeh and a white thawh? (Those white robe guys you saw were probably some of Sheriff Joe’s Klansmen, you dolt!) And would you be carrying a rocket launcher while sneaking in? Rob, I’d be willing to bet that you wouldn’t know what a rocket launcher looked like even if an RPG hit your Prius. But I hate to challenge you, rob, because you always provide such insight and reliable information. So let’s make a wager; If you produce one picture of an Arab with a rocket launcher crossing our border, I’ll trade you (even up) three pictures of Kate Middleton topless in the south of France, an original autographed photo of Glen Beck in his Nazi uniform from his book cover, a photo I have of black helicopters circling over your ghetto dwelling in Baltimore, a much coveted and only copy existing of a secret FEMA concentration camp cleverly hidden beneath a platform at the Fulton Street subway station in Manhattan, a Sara Palin blow-up doll once owned by Rush Limbaugh, a Joe McCarthy “Demagogues for Decency” lapel pin, an abridged version of Ted Kaczynski’s Unibomber Manifesto for speed readers, titled “I’m Wackier than Lavender”, and an Ann Coulter “Liberals Hate America” beer koozie. I’ll also buy you a beer to go in it if you throw in five years of Mitt Romney’s tax returns. Do we have a deal, Rob?

Topic.Title: Embassy attack - Romney does Obama's job

Message.Msg: The night after the first murder of an American ambassador in more than three decades, President Obama flew to Vegas for a campaign stop. The next day, he was rallying a crowd in Colorado. The campaign continues to make plans for swing-state visits next week in Ohio and Florida. Yet as more information emerges indicating the attack on the American Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, may have been a coordinated terror strike -- Sen. John McCain is the latest to declare it a "terrorist attack" -- some are questioning whether the president is acknowledging the severity of the situation. "We've seen numerous reports now of a growing intelligence trail that this was a planned attack," said Richard Grenell, Grenell questioned Obama's recent campaigns stops and media interviews in light of the tragedy. McCain, after an intelligence briefing Friday, said the Libya strike was carried out by terrorists and not a mere out-of-control mob. Speculation about the true root of the attack grew following a report in Britain's Independent claiming officials believe the attack was planned, that the State Department may have had warnings in advance and that sensitive documents have since gone missing from the Benghazi consulate. A State Department official reportedly told lawmakers Wednesday that he did think the assault was planned. And other lawmakers and analysts have reached the same conclusion. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Mike Rogers told Fox News shortly after the attack that it was clearly "coordinated." His account was backed up by a Libyan official Thursday who said it was a two-stage operation. The second stage involved an attack on a separate building that Americans consulate employees tried to take shelter in after the main building came under fire at 10 p.m. local time Tuesday. Two of the four Americans who died were killed in that second phase of the attack. The Independent report quoted a Libyan troop leader who assisted in the rescue operation that night saying "I don't know how they found the place to carry out the attack. It was planned, the accuracy with which the mortars hit us was too good for any ordinary revolutionaries." Eastern Libya's deputy interior minister was quoted Thursday saying the attacks may have been timed for the 11th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. "This was not just about any sort of a spontaneous revolt. This was an organized attack," he said. After a week on the campaign trail, Obama is back in Washington Friday, though he does have a private campaign event planned for Friday evening. The Romney campaign, though, is criticizing the president's approach -- not just this week, but over the course of his administration. "There's a pretty compelling story that if you had a President Romney, you'd be in a different situation," Romney foreign policy adviser Richard Williamson told The Washington Post, claiming "respect for America has gone down." He called it "amateur hour."

Topic.Title: short selling

Message.Msg: This board revolves more around politics than AT&T so it will not be out to pasture for a while. Short selling looks like the way to go for T next week. However it is no get rich quick strategy. Even though Stifel Nicolaus was the second downgrade in just two day and the third for this year, none of them have said sell. Of the 39 analysts that follow AT&T none recommend selling. However 22 say hold. Volume was high on the way down today and I think we will be back to around $36.40 next week.

Topic.Title: Wow - what a mess

Message.Msg: Yes. Stifel Nicolaus downgraded from buy to hold and it was the second downgrade this week. There are 39 analysts following AT&T and 22 say hold. None say sell. Volume was high on the sell off so expect it to continue Monday. The current price is right on the 20 DMA and the lower Bollinger Band is at $36.19 so I don't expect a major drop. The four day run up this week was probably not justified since iPhone5 is not going to result in an increase in profit for a couple years. My guess is funds are selling T so they can invest where they get some of the profit from financial companies that will benefit from 40 Billion a month in Mortgage Bonds.

Message.Title: After Hours Quotes...
Message.Msg: ...“Errors using inadequate data are much less than those using no data at all.” – Charles Babbage “Peace hath higher tests of manhood, than battle ever knew.” – John Greenleaf Whittier “In Florida, President Obama visited a pizzeria. The owner gave him a bear hug and lifted him off his feet. Everybody shared a good laugh and then the Secret Service shot the man in the face.” – Conan O’Brien “Always put off till tomorrow what you shouldn't do at all.” - anonymous “Conservatives define themselves in terms of what they oppose.” – George Will “The Conventions were so different. The Democrats finally look like a real political party; the Republicans look like a seminar for how to flip real estate for Jesus.” – Bill Maher “Nostalgia isn’t what it used to be.” – Peter Vries “Man is the animal that intends to shoot himself out into interplanetary space, after having given up on the problem of an efficient way to get himself five miles to work and back each day.” – Bill Vaughn "It seems only 96,000 jobs were added last month. And half of those were strippers working the conventions." –Jay Leno “What most persons consider as virtue, after the age of 40 is simply a loss of energy.” - Voltaire “Peace cannot be kept by force. It can only be achieved by understanding. You cannot subjugate a nation forcibly unless you wipe out every man, woman, and child. Unless you wish to use such drastic measures, you must find a way of settling your disputes without resort to arms.” – Albert Einstein, 1930 “President Obama spoke last night. The speech must have been pretty good because today Clint Eastwood announced he’s voting for the chair.” – Bill Maher “No society can surely be flourishing and happy, of which the far greater part of the members are poor and miserable.” – Adam Smith

Message.Title: AHQ (cont.)...
Message.Msg: ...“I said to my friends that if I was going to starve, I might as well starve where the food is good.” – Virgil Thomson "Everyone is still talking about Bill Clinton's speech last night in Charlotte. It was a remarkable speech, 45 minutes long and 6,000 words. Like the political version of the guitar solo from 'Freebird’.” – Craig Ferguson – Freebird link here, oh, sorry, yahoo board improvements prevent that from happening, but you can find it elsewhere – pay attention, yahoo. "Clinton was just devastating in his simplicity. He said, 'I came from a place where people still thought 2 and 2 was four.' And over at Fox News they said, 'Get the fact checkers on that’!” – Bill Maher “Of course, the humans in Haiti have hope. They hope to leave.” – P.J. O’Rourke “I am on the right wing of the middle of the road and with a strong radical bias.” - unknown “Character is power.” – Booker T. Washington “A process which led from the amoeba to man appeared to the philosophers to be obviously a progress -- though whether the amoeba would agree with this opinion is not known.” – Bertrand Russell “It really was a dream night for Bill Clinton – Democrats in love with him, hanging on his every word,Hillary was in China 10,000 miles away. We don't even know if she saw the speech. In fact, someone said to her today, 'Did you catch Bill in Charlotte?' And he said, 'Who's Charlotte’?” - Bill Maher “All children are born Atheists; they have no idea of God. Are they then criminal on account of their ignorance?” – Paul-Henri Holbach “Existence really is an imperfect tense that never becomes a present.” – Friedrich Nietzsche “As your attorney, I advise you to take a hit out of the little brown bottle in my shaving kit. You won't need much, just a tiny taste.” – Hunter S. Thompson “…the odour of Burgundy, and the smell of French sauces, and the sight of clean napkins and long loaves, knocked as a very welcome visitor at the door of our inner man.” – Jerome K. Jerome

Message.Title: AHQ (final)...
Message.Msg: ... “The trouble ain't that there is too many fools, but that the lightning ain't distributed right.” – Mark Twain “It was my Uncle George who discovered that alcohol was a food well in advance of modern medical thought.” – P.G. Wodehouse “Members of Mitt Romney's own party are starting to criticize him for being too vague. When asked if that bothers him, Romney said, 'Maybe’.” - Jimmy Fallon "Poetry is the journal of a sea animal living on land, wanting to fly in the sky." - Carl Sandburg “Another belief of mine: that everyone else my age is an adult, whereas I am merely in disguise.” – Margaret Atwood “Mitt, you just keep demanding that Americans answer the question: are you better off than you were four years ago? But just don't answer it yourself, cause that would mean releasing more than two years of tax returns." – Stephen Colbert “What is man in the midst of nature? A nothing in comparison with the infinite, an all in comparison with nothingness: a mean between nothing and all. Infinitely far from comprehending the extremes, the end of things and their principle are for him inevitably concealed in an impenetrable secret; equally incapable of seeing the nothingness whence he is derived, and the infinity in which he is swallowed up.” – Blaise Pascal “All autobiographies are alibi-ographies.” – Clare Boothe Luce “Knowledge is the most democratic source of power.” – Alvin Toffler “Show me a friend in need and I'll show you a pest.” - anonymous “It is well to remember that there are five reasons for drinking: the arrival of a friend; one's present or future thirst; the excellence of the wine; or any other reason.”- Latin Proverb “Help us to be ever faithful gardeners of the spirit, who know that without darkness nothing comes to birth, and without light nothing flowers.” – May Sarton "Of course, Clinton’s speech at the Democratic Convention made the Republicans furious. They said, 'No fair. Not everyone has an ex-president who can speak’.” - Bill Maher “Have a good weekend, all.” – echo2165 “The repose of sleep refreshes only the body. It rarely sets the soul at rest. The repose of the night does not belong to us. It is not the possession of our being. Sleep opens within us an inn for phantoms. In the morning we must sweep out the shadows.” – Gaston Bachelard

Topic.Title: AHQ (final)...

Message.Title: T Down today will be up Monday
Message.Msg: ON CNBC T was talked today: A downgrade of wireless carriers following the release of Apple’s [AAPL 691.28 8.30 (+1.22%) ] iPhone 5 on Friday elicited a swift, decisive backlash from Stephen Weiss of Short Hills Capital. On CNBC’s “Fast Money,” Stifel Nicolaus Senior Telecom Services Analyst Christopher King expanded on the morning’s downgrade: “We estimate it could be as much as $10 billion in subsidies just between Verizon [VZ 44.53 -1.05 (-2.3%) ] and AT&T [T 37.26 -0.89 (-2.33%) ] between now and the end of the year. So clearly, earnings estimates need to be trimmed.” Weiss minced no words. “First of all, you’re wrong,” he said. “This is the most obvious trade. It happens every, single time we launch a phone, No. 1. (Read More: iPhone 5 to Help Economy More Than Fed: Ex-Official) “No. 2, Verizon came out the other day and said that they don’t expect much of a hit to margin. “No. 3, the subsidies did change. As a matter of fact, I ordered two iPhones today from Verizon, and I had an all-you-can-eat data plan. They said, ‘Hey, you can keep that, but you’re going to have to pay full price for the phone.’ If you want the subsidy for the phone, you’ve got to come down to a share-everything plan, which is going to take your data usage to only 10 gigabytes vs. unlimited.” Weiss argued that the move would increase margins by doing away with the subsidy Verizon was providing for new iPhone users. Other mobile carriers with iPhone exposure include Sprint [S 5.26 0.06 (+1.15%) ], MetroPCS [PCS 10.63 0.15 (+1.43%) ] and Leap Wireless [LEAP 6.07 0.04 (+0.66%) ]. Weiss said the downgrade provided him with a trade. “I don’t think on a very, very obvious trade you downgrade a stock where they’re going pick up significantly more users, No. 1, and the yield is still extremely attractive. So I’d buy more, down a buck. Thank you for the opportunity.”
